cot.content:
To solve the problem, Please think and reason step by step, then answer.
question:
Who built the original Palace of Versailles that was enlarged by Louis XIV?
        
Generation Format:
Reasoning process:
Answer:

Reasoning process: The original Palace of Versailles was initially a hunting lodge built by Louis XIII in the early 17th century. Louis XIV, his son, later transformed and expanded it into the grand palace we recognize today. Therefore, the original construction can be attributed to Louis XIII.

Answer: Louis XIII built the original Palace of Versailles.

anchoring.content:
You are a cognitive scientist, to answer the following question:
Who built the original Palace of Versailles that was enlarged by Louis XIV?
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
['The most important showcase of the French Baroque was the Palace of Versailles. It was begun in 1624 by Louis XIII as a hunting lodge. In 1634, Louis XIII had it enlarged into a chateau by his chief architect and engineer, Philibert Le Roy. In 1661, Louis XIV decided to enlarge it further, without destroying the original. He commissioned Louis Le Vau and Charles le Brun as his architect and designer, and assigned André Le Nôtre to create a grand formal garden that could be viewed from the Chateau, on the model of Vaux-le-Vicomte. When Le Vau died in 1670, the project was given to Jules Hardouin-Mansart, the nephew of Francois Mansart.\n', "Louis XIII's successor, Louis XIV, had a great interest in Versailles. He settled on the royal hunting lodge at Versailles, and over the following decades had it expanded into one of the largest palaces in the world. Beginning in 1661, the architect Louis Le Vau, landscape architect André Le Nôtre, and painter-decorator Charles Lebrun began a detailed renovation and expansion of the château. This was done to fulfill Louis XIV's desire to establish a new centre for the royal court. Following the Treaties of Nijmegen in 1678, he began to gradually move the court to Versailles. The court was officially established there on 6 May 1682.\n", 'Based on the success of Vaux le Vicomte, Louis XIV selected Le Vau to construct an immense new palace at Versailles, to augment a smaller palace transformed from a hunting lodge by Louis XIII. This gradually became, over the decades, the master work of the Louis XIV style. Following the death of Le Vau in 1680, Jules Hardouin-Mansart took over the Versailles project; he broke away from the picturesque projections and dome and made a more sober and uniform facade of columns, with a flat roof topped by a balustrade and row of columns (1681). He used the same style to harmonize the other new buildings he created at Versailles, including the Orangerie and the Stables. Hardouin-Mansart constructed the Grand Trianon (completed 1687), single-story royal retreat with arched windows alternating with pairs of columns, and a flat roof and balustrade.\n', 'BULLET::::- 1660s – Louis XIV, with the architect Jules Hardouin-Mansart, begins to enlarge the Palace of Versailles (1661).\n', 'BULLET::::- The Palace of Versailles is first built by Louis XIII, as a hunting lodge.\n', 'With the signing of the Treaty of Nijmegen in 1678, which ended the Dutch War, the third building campaign at Versailles began (1678–1684). Under the direction of the architect, Jules Hardouin-Mansart, the Palace of Versailles acquired much of the look that it has today. In addition to the Hall of Mirrors, Hardouin-Mansart designed the north and south wings, which were used, respectively, by the nobility and Princes of the Blood, and the "Orangerie". Le Brun was occupied not only with the interior decoration of the new additions of the palace, but also collaborated with Le Nôtre\'s in landscaping the palace gardens. As symbol of France\'s new prominence as a European super-power, Louis XIV officially installed his court at Versailles in May 1682.\n', "Over the course of four building campaigns, Louis converted a hunting lodge built by Louis XIII into the spectacular Palace of Versailles. With the exception of the current Royal Chapel (built near the end of Louis' reign), the palace achieved much of its current appearance after the third building campaign, which was followed by an official move of the royal court to Versailles on 6 May 1682. Versailles became a dazzling, awe-inspiring setting for state affairs and the reception of foreign dignitaries. At Versailles, the king alone commanded attention.\n", 'In 1654 Cardinal Mazarin commissioned the royal architect Louis Le Vau to build a new palace for King Louis XIV next to the chateau. The new palace featured a pavilion for the King and another for the Queen, separated by a portico and by a wall connected by arcades to the medieval section of the chateau. The donjon had been transformed into prison in the 15th century. The palace was popular with the King for a time, but once Louis XIV established his residence at Versailles, the château of Vincennes was rarely used.\n', 'The most famous Baroque gardens were the Gardens of Versailles created by Le Notre between 1662 and 1666. It was built around the original small square park of ninety-three hectares before the chateau started for Louis XIII by Jacques Boyceau in 1638. In 1662 following the model of Vaux-le-Vicomte, Le Notre made the park ten times larger, centered on a grand canal which reached to the horizon. The new park was divided into an elaborate grid of flowerbeds, paths, and alleys, decorated with fountains and sculptures. A third enlargement expanded the park by another six thousand five hundred hectares, including forests for hunting and several nearby villages, surrounded by a wall forty-three kilometres long with twenty-two gates.\n', 'The Versailles Synagogue is situated at 10, rue Albert Joly in Versailles in the Department of Yvelines. It is one of the oldest Synagogues in the Île-de-France. Built between 1884 and 1886 by the architect Alfred-Philibert Aldrophe (1834–1895), it was inaugurated in 1886.\n']

Task Description:

To answer the question of who built the original Palace of Versailles that was later enlarged by Louis XIV, we can extract and analyze relevant content from the provided passages. 

### Key Extracted Content:

1. **Original Construction**:
   - "The Palace of Versailles was begun in 1624 by Louis XIII as a hunting lodge."
   - "In 1634, Louis XIII had it enlarged into a chateau by his chief architect and engineer, Philibert Le Roy."

2. **Subsequent Enlargements**:
   - "In 1661, Louis XIV decided to enlarge it further, without destroying the original."
   - "He commissioned Louis Le Vau and Charles le Brun as his architect and designer, and assigned André Le Nôtre to create a grand formal garden."

3. **Architectural Contributions**:
   - "Following the death of Le Vau in 1670, the project was given to Jules Hardouin-Mansart."
   - "Under the direction of the architect, Jules Hardouin-Mansart, the Palace of Versailles acquired much of the look that it has today."

### Analysis of the Extracted Content:

1. **Historical Context**:
   - The original construction of the Palace of Versailles by Louis XIII in 1624 as a hunting lodge provides essential historical context. It highlights the initial purpose of the site and its transformation over time. Understanding this context is crucial for grasping the significance of the palace in French history.

2. **Architectural Development**:
   - The mention of Philibert Le Roy as the chief architect during the enlargement of the hunting lodge into a chateau under Louis XIII is significant. It introduces the idea that the palace's architectural evolution involved multiple key figures and phases, which is important for understanding the complexity of its design.

3. **Louis XIV's Vision**:
   - Louis XIV's decision to further enlarge the palace and his commissioning of prominent architects like Louis Le Vau and Jules Hardouin-Mansart illustrates his ambition to create a grand royal residence. This reflects the broader historical narrative of the absolute monarchy in France and the importance of Versailles as a symbol of royal power.

4. **Cultural Significance**:
   - The transformation of Versailles into a center for the royal court under Louis XIV, culminating in the official establishment of the court there in 1682, underscores the palace's role not just as a residence but as a political and cultural hub. This aspect is vital for understanding the palace's significance in French history and its impact on European architecture and court life.

### Conclusion:

The extracted content provides a comprehensive background on the origins of the Palace of Versailles, its architectural evolution, and its cultural significance. This knowledge is essential for answering the question accurately, as it highlights that the original palace was built by Louis XIII, with significant contributions from his architect Philibert Le Roy, before being enlarged by Louis XIV and his chosen architects. Understanding these details enriches the model's comprehension of the historical and architectural context surrounding the Palace of Versailles.

### Knowledge Enhanced Inference Process:

To determine who built the original Palace of Versailles that was later enlarged by Louis XIV, we can analyze the historical context and architectural developments surrounding the palace's construction.

1. **Original Construction**:
   - The Palace of Versailles was initiated in 1624 by Louis XIII, originally serving as a hunting lodge. This foundational purpose is crucial as it sets the stage for the palace's evolution into a grand royal residence.
   - In 1634, Louis XIII had the hunting lodge expanded into a chateau, with the assistance of his chief architect and engineer, Philibert Le Roy. This indicates that the original structure underwent significant changes under Louis XIII's direction.

2. **Subsequent Enlargements**:
   - Louis XIV, who succeeded Louis XIII, recognized the potential of Versailles and decided to further enlarge it starting in 1661. His vision was to create a magnificent palace that would serve as the center of the royal court.
   - He commissioned notable architects, including Louis Le Vau and Charles Le Brun, to oversee the expansion, while André Le Nôtre was tasked with designing the extensive gardens that would complement the palace.

3. **Architectural Contributions**:
   - After the death of Louis Le Vau in 1670, Jules Hardouin-Mansart took over the project, leading to the palace acquiring much of its current appearance. This highlights the collaborative nature of the architectural development, with multiple key figures contributing to the palace's grandeur.

4. **Cultural and Historical Significance**:
   - The transformation of Versailles into a political and cultural hub under Louis XIV, culminating in the official establishment of the royal court there in 1682, underscores the palace's importance in French history. It became a symbol of absolute monarchy and a center for state affairs and diplomacy.

5. **Conclusion**:
   - The original construction of the Palace of Versailles can be attributed to Louis XIII, with significant contributions from Philibert Le Roy. Louis XIV later expanded and transformed it into the grand palace recognized today, showcasing the evolution of royal architecture and the centralization of power in France.

### Answer:
Louis XIII built the original Palace of Versailles.

### Foundational Knowledge:
1. **Original Construction**: The Palace of Versailles was originally built by Louis XIII as a hunting lodge starting in 1624. This foundational aspect establishes the initial purpose and context of the site before it became the grand palace we know today.

2. **Initial Architect**: The original structure was enlarged into a chateau by Louis XIII's chief architect, Philibert Le Roy, in 1634. This detail highlights the role of architectural expertise in the early development of Versailles.

3. **Louis XIV's Expansion**: Louis XIV, who succeeded Louis XIII, significantly expanded the palace beginning in 1661. He commissioned architects Louis Le Vau and later Jules Hardouin-Mansart to oversee this transformation. This indicates a shift from a hunting lodge to a monumental royal residence, reflecting the ambitions of Louis XIV to establish a new center for the royal court.

4. **Architectural Evolution**: The passages detail the evolution of the palace through various building campaigns, emphasizing the contributions of different architects and designers. This includes the transformation of the gardens by André Le Nôtre and the interior designs by Charles Le Brun, showcasing the collaborative nature of the project.

5. **Cultural Significance**: The expansion of Versailles under Louis XIV not only transformed its physical structure but also its role as a symbol of royal power and a center for state affairs, culminating in the official establishment of the royal court there in 1682.

### Advanced Information:
1. **Design Philosophy**: The architectural style that emerged during Louis XIV's reign, often referred to as the "Louis XIV style," reflects the grandeur and opulence associated with the Baroque period. This style was characterized by symmetry, grandeur, and elaborate decoration, which became hallmarks of the palace.

2. **Gardens and Landscape**: The transformation of the gardens into an elaborate Baroque landscape by Le Nôtre is significant, as it not only enhanced the aesthetic appeal of the palace but also served as a representation of the power and control of nature by the monarchy.

3. **Subsequent Developments**: The ongoing renovations and expansions, including the construction of the Hall of Mirrors and the Grand Trianon, illustrate the continuous evolution of Versailles as a royal residence and a cultural landmark.

### Role of the Extracted Information:
The extracted foundational and advanced knowledge serves to deepen the understanding of the original question by providing a comprehensive overview of the historical context, architectural developments, and cultural significance of the Palace of Versailles. Recognizing that Louis XIII initiated the construction and that Louis XIV expanded it allows for a clearer understanding of the palace's evolution from a simple hunting lodge to a symbol of absolute monarchy and French grandeur.

In summary, the original Palace of Versailles was built by Louis XIII, with significant enlargements and renovations carried out by Louis XIV and his appointed architects, marking a pivotal transformation in French royal architecture and culture. This understanding not only answers the question but also situates Versailles within a broader historical narrative of power, art, and landscape design in France.

### Knowledge Enhanced Inference Process:

To answer the question of who built the original Palace of Versailles that was later enlarged by Louis XIV, we can draw upon both foundational and advanced knowledge extracted from the provided passages.

1. **Original Construction**: The Palace of Versailles was initially constructed by Louis XIII, starting in 1624 as a hunting lodge. This establishes the context of the site as a royal retreat before its transformation into a grand palace.

2. **Architectural Contributions**: The original lodge was expanded into a chateau by Louis XIII's chief architect, Philibert Le Roy, in 1634. This highlights the importance of architectural expertise in the early development of Versailles, setting the stage for future expansions.

3. **Louis XIV's Ambitions**: After Louis XIII's death, his son, Louis XIV, recognized the potential of Versailles and began significant expansions in 1661. He commissioned prominent architects such as Louis Le Vau and later Jules Hardouin-Mansart to transform the chateau into a monumental royal residence. This reflects Louis XIV's desire to establish Versailles as the center of political power and royal court life.

4. **Collaborative Architectural Evolution**: The expansion of Versailles involved a collaborative effort among various architects and designers. Notably, André Le Nôtre designed the gardens, and Charles Le Brun contributed to the interior decoration. This collaborative approach underscores the palace's evolution into a symbol of Baroque grandeur and royal authority.

5. **Cultural and Political Significance**: The transformation of Versailles under Louis XIV not only altered its physical structure but also its role in French society. By officially moving the royal court to Versailles in 1682, Louis XIV elevated the palace to a central position in the political and cultural life of France, making it a symbol of absolute monarchy.

6. **Architectural Style**: The architectural style that emerged during Louis XIV's reign, often referred to as the "Louis XIV style," is characterized by its grandeur, symmetry, and elaborate decoration, which became defining features of the palace. This style reflects the broader Baroque movement and the king's vision of royal power.

7. **Gardens as Symbols of Power**: The gardens designed by Le Nôtre not only enhanced the aesthetic appeal of Versailles but also symbolized the monarchy's control over nature, reinforcing the idea of the king as a powerful ruler.

### Conclusion:
By synthesizing this foundational and advanced knowledge, we gain a comprehensive understanding of the original Palace of Versailles and its evolution. Louis XIII's initial construction as a hunting lodge laid the groundwork for Louis XIV's ambitious expansions, which transformed it into a symbol of royal power and cultural significance.

### Answer:
Louis XIII built the original Palace of Versailles.

Under the direction of the architect, Jules Hardouin-Mansart, the Palace of Versailles acquired much of the look that it has today. In addition to the Hall of Mirrors, Hardouin-Mansart designed the north and south wings, which were used, respectively, by the nobility and Princes of the Blood, and the "Orangerie". Le Brun was occupied not only with the interior decoration of the new additions of the palace, but also collaborated with Le Nôtre's in landscaping the palace gardens. As symbol of France's new prominence as a European super-power, Louis XIV officially installed his court at Versailles in May 1682.
', "Over the course of four building campaigns, Louis converted a hunting lodge built by Louis XIII into the spectacular Palace of Versailles. With the exception of the current Royal Chapel (built near the end of Louis' reign), the palace achieved much of its current appearance after the third building campaign, which was followed by an official move of the royal court to Versailles on 6 May 1682. Versailles became a dazzling, awe-inspiring setting for state affairs and the reception of foreign dignitaries. At Versailles, the king alone commanded attention.
", 'In 1654 Cardinal Mazarin commissioned the royal architect Louis Le Vau to build a new palace for King Louis XIV next to the chateau. The new palace featured a pavilion for the King and another for the Queen, separated by a portico and by a wall connected by arcades to the medieval section of the chateau. The donjon had been transformed into prison in the 15th century. The palace was popular with the King for a time, but once Louis XIV established his residence at Versailles, the château of Vincennes was rarely used.
', 'The most famous Baroque gardens were the Gardens of Versailles created by Le Notre between 1662 and 1666. It was built around the original small square park of ninety-three hectares before the chateau started for Louis XIII by Jacques Boyceau in 1638. In 1662 following the model of Vaux-le-Vicomte, Le Notre made the park ten times larger, centered on a grand canal which reached to the horizon. The new park was divided into an elaborate grid of flowerbeds, paths, and alleys, decorated with fountains and sculptures. A third enlargement expanded the park by another six thousand five hundred hectares, including forests for hunting and several nearby villages, surrounded by a wall forty-three kilometres long with twenty-two gates.
', 'The Versailles Synagogue is situated at 10, rue Albert Joly in Versailles in the Department of Yvelines. It is one of the oldest Synagogues in the Île-de-France. Built between 1884 and 1886 by the architect Alfred-Philibert Aldrophe (1834–1895), it was inaugurated in 1886.
']

Task Description:
Please extract content from these passages that can help enhance the model's causal reasoning and logical inference abilities.
consolidate these contents, and analyze how the selected information may impact the improvement of the model's causal reasoning and logical inference capabilities.

To enhance the model's causal reasoning and logical inference abilities, we can extract and consolidate the relevant information from the provided passages regarding the construction and expansion of the Palace of Versailles. Here’s a summary of the key points:

1. **Original Construction**: The Palace of Versailles was originally built by **Louis XIII** as a hunting lodge starting in **1624**. It was initially a modest structure.

2. **First Enlargement**: In **1634**, Louis XIII had the hunting lodge enlarged into a chateau by his chief architect, **Philibert Le Roy**.

3. **Further Expansions by Louis XIV**: After Louis XIII, **Louis XIV** took a significant interest in Versailles and began a series of expansions starting in **1661**. He commissioned **Louis Le Vau** as the architect and **Charles Le Brun** as the designer, with **André Le Nôtre** responsible for the gardens.

4. **Architectural Evolution**: Following the death of Louis Le Vau in **1670**, the project was continued by **Jules Hardouin-Mansart**, who made substantial changes to the palace's design, contributing to its current appearance.

5. **Significance of the Expansions**: The expansions transformed Versailles from a hunting lodge into one of the largest and most magnificent palaces in the world, serving as a center for the royal court from **1682** onward.

### Analysis of Impact on Causal Reasoning and Logical Inference:

1. **Understanding Causality**: The extracted information illustrates a clear causal relationship between the actions of Louis XIII and Louis XIV and the evolution of the Palace of Versailles. Recognizing that Louis XIII's initial construction set the foundation for Louis XIV's grand vision helps the model understand how historical actions lead to subsequent developments.

2. **Temporal Sequencing**: The timeline of events (from 1624 to 1682) provides a framework for understanding how different phases of construction and design contributed to the palace's final form. This temporal aspect is crucial for logical inference, as it allows the model to deduce the order of events and their interdependencies.

3. **Role of Key Figures**: Identifying the roles of various architects and designers (Philibert Le Roy, Louis Le Vau, Charles Le Brun, and Jules Hardouin-Mansart) helps the model infer how individual contributions can collectively lead to significant outcomes. This understanding can be generalized to other contexts where multiple agents contribute to a single result.

4. **Architectural and Cultural Significance**: The transformation of Versailles into a symbol of royal power and cultural prominence illustrates how physical structures can embody broader social and political changes. This insight can enhance the model's ability to make inferences about the relationship between architecture and societal values.

5. **Complex Systems**: The expansion of the Palace of Versailles can be viewed as a complex system where various elements (architectural design, landscaping, royal ambitions) interact. Understanding this complexity can improve the model's reasoning about systems with multiple interconnected components.

By consolidating these insights, the model can better grasp causal relationships, infer logical connections, and understand the implications of historical events, thereby enhancing its overall reasoning capabilities.

Here is an answer generated by a language model with the reasoning process.
question:
Who built the original Palace of Versailles that was enlarged by Louis XIV?
answer:
Reasoning process: The original Palace of Versailles was initially a hunting lodge built by Louis XIII in the early 17th century. Louis XIV, his son, later transformed and expanded it into the grand palace we recognize today. Therefore, the original construction can be attributed to Louis XIII.

Answer: Louis XIII built the original Palace of Versailles.

By **1682**, it became the official residence of the royal court, symbolizing the absolute power of Louis XIV and the cultural prominence of France.

cognition.content:
Fact-checking refers to the process of confirming the accuracy of a statement or claim through various sources or methods. 
This process aims to ensure that statements or claims are based on reliable and verifiable information while eliminating inaccurate or misleading content. 
Fact-checking may involve the examination of data, literature, expert opinions, or other trustworthy sources.
In the context of artificial intelligence, model illusion refers to the overconfidence response of the AI. 
When a model exhibits an 'illusion' (a tendency to output deceptive data), it indicates that the training data used by the model does not necessarily support the rationality of its outputs.
You are a scientist researching fact-checking and addressing model illusions in artificial intelligence. 
To answer the following question:
Who built the original Palace of Versailles that was enlarged by Louis XIV?
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
['The most important showcase of the French Baroque was the Palace of Versailles. It was begun in 1624 by Louis XIII as a hunting lodge. In 1634, Louis XIII had it enlarged into a chateau by his chief architect and engineer, Philibert Le Roy. In 1661, Louis XIV decided to enlarge it further, without destroying the original. He commissioned Louis Le Vau and Charles le Brun as his architect and designer, and assigned André Le Nôtre to create a grand formal garden that could be viewed from the Chateau, on the model of Vaux-le-Vicomte. When Le Vau died in 1670, the project was given to Jules Hardouin-Mansart, the nephew of Francois Mansart.\n', "Louis XIII's successor, Louis XIV, had a great interest in Versailles. He settled on the royal hunting lodge at Versailles, and over the following decades had it expanded into one of the largest palaces in the world. Beginning in 1661, the architect Louis Le Vau, landscape architect André Le Nôtre, and painter-decorator Charles Lebrun began a detailed renovation and expansion of the château. This was done to fulfill Louis XIV's desire to establish a new centre for the royal court. Following the Treaties of Nijmegen in 1678, he began to gradually move the court to Versailles. The court was officially established there on 6 May 1682.\n", 'Based on the success of Vaux le Vicomte, Louis XIV selected Le Vau to construct an immense new palace at Versailles, to augment a smaller palace transformed from a hunting lodge by Louis XIII. This gradually became, over the decades, the master work of the Louis XIV style. Following the death of Le Vau in 1680, Jules Hardouin-Mansart took over the Versailles project; he broke away from the picturesque projections and dome and made a more sober and uniform facade of columns, with a flat roof topped by a balustrade and row of columns (1681). He used the same style to harmonize the other new buildings he created at Versailles, including the Orangerie and the Stables. Hardouin-Mansart constructed the Grand Trianon (completed 1687), single-story royal retreat with arched windows alternating with pairs of columns, and a flat roof and balustrade.\n', 'BULLET::::- 1660s – Louis XIV, with the architect Jules Hardouin-Mansart, begins to enlarge the Palace of Versailles (1661).\n', 'BULLET::::- The Palace of Versailles is first built by Louis XIII, as a hunting lodge.\n', 'With the signing of the Treaty of Nijmegen in 1678, which ended the Dutch War, the third building campaign at Versailles began (1678–1684). Under the direction of the architect, Jules Hardouin-Mansart, the Palace of Versailles acquired much of the look that it has today. In addition to the Hall of Mirrors, Hardouin-Mansart designed the north and south wings, which were used, respectively, by the nobility and Princes of the Blood, and the "Orangerie". Le Brun was occupied not only with the interior decoration of the new additions of the palace, but also collaborated with Le Nôtre\'s in landscaping the palace gardens. As symbol of France\'s new prominence as a European super-power, Louis XIV officially installed his court at Versailles in May 1682.\n', "Over the course of four building campaigns, Louis converted a hunting lodge built by Louis XIII into the spectacular Palace of Versailles. With the exception of the current Royal Chapel (built near the end of Louis' reign), the palace achieved much of its current appearance after the third building campaign, which was followed by an official move of the royal court to Versailles on 6 May 1682. Versailles became a dazzling, awe-inspiring setting for state affairs and the reception of foreign dignitaries. At Versailles, the king alone commanded attention.\n", 'In 1654 Cardinal Mazarin commissioned the royal architect Louis Le Vau to build a new palace for King Louis XIV next to the chateau. The new palace featured a pavilion for the King and another for the Queen, separated by a portico and by a wall connected by arcades to the medieval section of the chateau. The donjon had been transformed into prison in the 15th century. The palace was popular with the King for a time, but once Louis XIV established his residence at Versailles, the château of Vincennes was rarely used.\n', 'The most famous Baroque gardens were the Gardens of Versailles created by Le Notre between 1662 and 1666. It was built around the original small square park of ninety-three hectares before the chateau started for Louis XIII by Jacques Boyceau in 1638. In 1662 following the model of Vaux-le-Vicomte, Le Notre made the park ten times larger, centered on a grand canal which reached to the horizon. The new park was divided into an elaborate grid of flowerbeds, paths, and alleys, decorated with fountains and sculptures. A third enlargement expanded the park by another six thousand five hundred hectares, including forests for hunting and several nearby villages, surrounded by a wall forty-three kilometres long with twenty-two gates.\n', 'The Versailles Synagogue is situated at 10, rue Albert Joly in Versailles in the Department of Yvelines. It is one of the oldest Synagogues in the Île-de-France. Built between 1884 and 1886 by the architect Alfred-Philibert Aldrophe (1834–1895), it was inaugurated in 1886.\n']

1. **Original Construction by Louis XIII**: The passages confirm that the Palace of Versailles was originally built by Louis XIII as a hunting lodge, which is consistent with historical knowledge. However, it is important to note that the initial construction began in **1624** and was later enlarged into a chateau in **1634** by Louis XIII's chief architect, Philibert Le Roy.

2. **Enlargement by Louis XIV**: The passages detail that Louis XIV began significant enlargements of the palace starting in **1661**, with the involvement of architects Louis Le Vau and later Jules Hardouin-Mansart. This information reinforces the understanding that Louis XIV transformed the original structure into a grand palace.

3. **Architectural Contributions**: The passages highlight the roles of various architects and designers in the expansion of Versailles:
   - **Louis Le Vau** was initially commissioned by Louis XIV for the renovations.
   - **Jules Hardouin-Mansart** took over after Le Vau's death and was responsible for much of the palace's current appearance, including the Hall of Mirrors and the north and south wings.
   - **André Le Nôtre** was responsible for the landscaping of the gardens.

4. **Building Campaigns**: The passages mention multiple building campaigns, particularly noting that the third campaign (1678–1684) was crucial in shaping the palace's appearance. This detail emphasizes the gradual nature of the palace's transformation.

5. **Official Court Establishment**: The passages state that Louis XIV officially moved his court to Versailles on **May 6, 1682**, marking a significant moment in the palace's history and its role as a center of political power.

In summary, the model's knowledge could be updated with the following points:
- The Palace of Versailles was originally a hunting lodge built by Louis XIII, with significant enlargement starting in 1624 and completed in 1634.
- Louis XIV began extensive renovations and expansions in 1661, involving notable architects like Louis Le Vau and Jules Hardouin-Mansart.
- The palace underwent multiple building campaigns, with the third campaign being particularly influential in its final appearance.
- The official establishment of the royal court at Versailles occurred on May 6, 1682.

Incorporating these details can help prevent factual errors and alleviate model illusions regarding the history of the Palace of Versailles.

Generation Format:
knowledge enhanced inference process:
Answer:

**Knowledge Enhanced Inference Process:**

The original Palace of Versailles was initially constructed as a hunting lodge by Louis XIII in the early 17th century. The construction began in **1624**, and by **1634**, it was enlarged into a chateau under the guidance of Louis XIII's chief architect, Philibert Le Roy. This foundational work set the stage for the later, more extensive transformations.

Louis XIV, the son of Louis XIII, recognized the potential of Versailles and initiated significant renovations and expansions starting in **1661**. He commissioned prominent architects, including **Louis Le Vau**, who was responsible for the initial grand designs, and later **Jules Hardouin-Mansart**, who took over after Le Vau's death in **1670**. Mansart played a crucial role in shaping the palace's current appearance, including the iconic Hall of Mirrors and the north and south wings.

The construction of the palace occurred over several building campaigns, with the third campaign (1678–1684) being particularly influential in defining its final architectural style. Additionally, **André Le Nôtre** was instrumental in designing the expansive gardens that complement the palace.

A significant milestone in the history of Versailles was the official establishment of the royal court there on **May 6, 1682**, marking its transformation into a center of political power and royal authority in France.

In summary, the original construction of the Palace of Versailles can be attributed to Louis XIII, with significant expansions and renovations carried out by Louis XIV and his appointed architects. This understanding incorporates the timeline of construction, the roles of various architects, and the palace's evolution into a symbol of royal power.

**Answer:**
Louis XIII built the original Palace of Versailles, which was initially a hunting lodge constructed starting in 1624 and enlarged into a chateau by 1634. Louis XIV later transformed and expanded it into the grand palace we recognize today, beginning significant renovations in 1661.

question_info.question: Who built the original Palace of Versailles that was enlarged by Louis XIV?
passages:
The most important showcase of the French Baroque was the Palace of Versailles. It was begun in 1624 by Louis XIII as a hunting lodge. In 1634, Louis XIII had it enlarged into a chateau by his chief architect and engineer, Philibert Le Roy. In 1661, Louis XIV decided to enlarge it further, without destroying the original. He commissioned Louis Le Vau and Charles le Brun as his architect and designer, and assigned André Le Nôtre to create a grand formal garden that could be viewed from the Chateau, on the model of Vaux-le-Vicomte. When Le Vau died in 1670, the project was given to Jules Hardouin-Mansart, the nephew of Francois Mansart.
Louis XIII's successor, Louis XIV, had a great interest in Versailles. He settled on the royal hunting lodge at Versailles, and over the following decades had it expanded into one of the largest palaces in the world. Beginning in 1661, the architect Louis Le Vau, landscape architect André Le Nôtre, and painter-decorator Charles Lebrun began a detailed renovation and expansion of the château. This was done to fulfill Louis XIV's desire to establish a new centre for the royal court. Following the Treaties of Nijmegen in 1678, he began to gradually move the court to Versailles. The court was officially established there on 6 May 1682.
Based on the success of Vaux le Vicomte, Louis XIV selected Le Vau to construct an immense new palace at Versailles, to augment a smaller palace transformed from a hunting lodge by Louis XIII. This gradually became, over the decades, the master work of the Louis XIV style. Following the death of Le Vau in 1680, Jules Hardouin-Mansart took over the Versailles project; he broke away from the picturesque projections and dome and made a more sober and uniform facade of columns, with a flat roof topped by a balustrade and row of columns (1681). He used the same style to harmonize the other new buildings he created at Versailles, including the Orangerie and the Stables. Hardouin-Mansart constructed the Grand Trianon (completed 1687), single-story royal retreat with arched windows alternating with pairs of columns, and a flat roof and balustrade.
BULLET::::- 1660s – Louis XIV, with the architect Jules Hardouin-Mansart, begins to enlarge the Palace of Versailles (1661).
BULLET::::- The Palace of Versailles is first built by Louis XIII, as a hunting lodge.
With the signing of the Treaty of Nijmegen in 1678, which ended the Dutch War, the third building campaign at Versailles began (1678–1684). Under the direction of the architect, Jules Hardouin-Mansart, the Palace of Versailles acquired much of the look that it has today. In addition to the Hall of Mirrors, Hardouin-Mansart designed the north and south wings, which were used, respectively, by the nobility and Princes of the Blood, and the "Orangerie". Le Brun was occupied not only with the interior decoration of the new additions of the palace, but also collaborated with Le Nôtre's in landscaping the palace gardens. As symbol of France's new prominence as a European super-power, Louis XIV officially installed his court at Versailles in May 1682.
Over the course of four building campaigns, Louis converted a hunting lodge built by Louis XIII into the spectacular Palace of Versailles. With the exception of the current Royal Chapel (built near the end of Louis' reign), the palace achieved much of its current appearance after the third building campaign, which was followed by an official move of the royal court to Versailles on 6 May 1682. Versailles became a dazzling, awe-inspiring setting for state affairs and the reception of foreign dignitaries. At Versailles, the king alone commanded attention.
In 1654 Cardinal Mazarin commissioned the royal architect Louis Le Vau to build a new palace for King Louis XIV next to the chateau. The new palace featured a pavilion for the King and another for the Queen, separated by a portico and by a wall connected by arcades to the medieval section of the chateau. The donjon had been transformed into prison in the 15th century. The palace was popular with the King for a time, but once Louis XIV established his residence at Versailles, the château of Vincennes was rarely used.
The most famous Baroque gardens were the Gardens of Versailles created by Le Notre between 1662 and 1666. It was built around the original small square park of ninety-three hectares before the chateau started for Louis XIII by Jacques Boyceau in 1638. In 1662 following the model of Vaux-le-Vicomte, Le Notre made the park ten times larger, centered on a grand canal which reached to the horizon. The new park was divided into an elaborate grid of flowerbeds, paths, and alleys, decorated with fountains and sculptures. A third enlargement expanded the park by another six thousand five hundred hectares, including forests for hunting and several nearby villages, surrounded by a wall forty-three kilometres long with twenty-two gates.
The Versailles Synagogue is situated at 10, rue Albert Joly in Versailles in the Department of Yvelines. It is one of the oldest Synagogues in the Île-de-France. Built between 1884 and 1886 by the architect Alfred-Philibert Aldrophe (1834–1895), it was inaugurated in 1886.
